strategic_profile.executive_summary: The University at Buffalo-SUNY is a comprehensive public research university and one of the two flagship institutions of the SUNY system. It is the largest public university in New York State, offering a wide array of undergraduate and graduate programs and recognized for its high research activity.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Based on available information for graduate programs, there are minimum GPA requirements (e.g., 3.0 for PhD and MA Philosophy programs), suggesting a numbers-focused component. Undergraduate admissions criteria are not explicitly detailed as 'holistic' or 'numbers-focused' in the provided search results but general admission information and standardized test score requirements are mentioned, implying a review of academic credentials.

analyst_takeaways.insight: University at Buffalo consistently ranks among the top 75-80 National Universities and top 40 Public Universities by US News.
analyst_takeaways.implication: UB maintains a strong national and public university standing, appealing to students seeking a reputable public institution.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Designated as an R1: Doctoral University â€“ Very High Research Activity, UB offers extensive undergraduate research opportunities from the first year.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students interested in hands-on research and contributing to discoveries early in their academic careers will find numerous avenues at UB.

analyst_takeaways.insight: UB is recognized as a 'Best Value School' by U.S. News, ranking 40th among public universities nationally for 2026 and 42nd for 2025.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students seeking a high-quality education at a competitive price, especially within the public university system, should consider UB.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The overall acceptance rate is 69%. While specific undergraduate philosophy isn't detailed, graduate programs have minimum GPA requirements.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Admissions are somewhat competitive. Strong academic performance is likely a key factor, particularly for specialized graduate programs.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: The University at Buffalo offers a vibrant and inclusive social environment with over 500 student clubs and organizations, Division I athletics, concerts, and various events throughout the year. There are multiple residence halls and campus apartment communities, placing students at the heart of university life. The campus community is diverse and welcoming, with students from all 50 states and over 100 countries. While some students enjoy a lively party scene, others note the campus as conducive to studying.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: UB operates a free and efficient inter- and intra-campus transportation system with buses (Stampede) and shuttles connecting its three campuses (North, South, and Downtown). This facilitates easy movement between academic buildings, residence halls, and off-campus locations. For off-campus travel and local retailers, the UB Stampede and public transportation (NFTA buses and a Metro station on South Campus) are available. Parking permits are available for students with cars, and park-and-ride lots are an option to alleviate busy academic building parking. Biking is also encouraged with racks, free registration, and winter storage. A tunnel system on North Campus provides a warm and dry way to navigate between buildings during colder or rainy weather.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: As an R1 classified university, UB emphasizes a very high level of research activity, providing extensive opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students alike. Students can engage in hands-on research from their first year, working alongside faculty on scientific, creative, and societal challenges. Specific programs like the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) and Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) programs offer paid opportunities and real-world lab experience. UB also fosters interdisciplinary research, with initiatives like the new department of AI and Society, and encourages students to present their findings at various conferences.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Acceptance rate from Clastify and CDS. Enrolled total is first-time, first-year degree-seeking students. In-state/out-of-state acceptance rates calculated from CDS first-time, first-year data. Waitlist data from CDS 2024-2025.

Data primarily from CDS 2023-2024, Clastify, and GyanDhan. Enrolled total is first-time, first-year degree-seeking students. In-state/out-of-state acceptance rates calculated from CDS first-time, first-year data. Waitlist data from CDS 2023-2024. Clastify reported a 16.6% waitlist acceptance rate for 2023 with the same offers and admits as 2024, but the 'accepted_spots' was not explicitly stated there; using CDS value for accepted spots.

Data primarily from CDS 2022-2023, Clastify, and GyanDhan. Enrolled total is first-time, first-year degree-seeking students. In-state/out-of-state acceptance rates not publicly disclosed for this year. Waitlist data from CDS 2022-2023. Note that Clastify reported different waitlist admission numbers for 2022 (27 admitted from 1,948 offered), but the CDS 2022-2023 is prioritized.

Data primarily from CDS 2021-2022, Clastify, and GyanDhan. Enrolled total is first-time, first-year degree-seeking students. In-state/out-of-state acceptance rates not publicly disclosed for this year. Waitlist data from CDS 2021-2022.

Data primarily from CDS 2020-2021, Clastify, and GyanDhan. Enrolled total is first-time, first-year degree-seeking students. In-state/out-of-state acceptance rates not publicly disclosed for this year. Waitlist data for 'admitted_from_waitlist' taken from Clastify for 2021 (corresponding to Fall 2020 admissions), as CDS 2020-2021 did not explicitly state the number.

gpa.notes: Average weighted GPA for admitted students is 3.8, with an unweighted average of 3.6. The 25th percentile for weighted GPA is 3.5, and the 75th percentile is 3.9. For unweighted GPAs, the 25th percentile is 3.4 and the 75th percentile is 3.7.

testing.policy_note: Test optional; applicants can indicate whether they want to be considered test-optional. 60% of students submit SAT scores and 55% submit ACT scores.

men.note: For Fall 2024, there were 10,267 total undergraduate men.

women.note: For Fall 2024, there were 8,500 total undergraduate women.

non_binary.note: For Fall 2024, there were 5 total degree-seeking undergraduates of another gender, and 0 for non-degree seeking.

colleges.name: School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong high school academic performance in STEM, standardized test scores, and strong personal statements are crucial. Current UB students need a minimum 2.5 GPA in core courses and overall GPA requirements vary by major.
colleges.housing_profile: Modern dorms with maker spaces (implied by Engineering Living Learning Community) and access to academic support in residence halls.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers, innovative, dedicated to STEM fields.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: CSE 115 (Introduction to Computer Science for Majors 1)
CSE 116 (Introduction to Computer Science for Majors 2)
weeder_courses: CSE 115 Introduction to Computer Science for Majors 1
CSE 116 Introduction to Computer Science for Majors 2
majors.special_requirements: Must meet minimum grades in prerequisite courses for internal transfer review by the department.
majors.notes: Transfer students are evaluated by the department. General UB acceptance rate is around 68-69%. MS in CS acceptance rate is around 25-30% for international students.

majors.name: Aerospace Engineering
majors.special_requirements: All engineering majors require MTH 141. EAS 360 (STEM Communications) is also a required course for all SEAS majors.
majors.notes: Typically requires strong performance in foundational math and science courses. Mentioned as a common double major with Mechanical Engineering.

majors.name: Biomedical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Major application is not required at the time of acceptance to UB. The department reviews major course GPA after admission to UB.
majors.notes: The Jacobs School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences at UB is known for competitive programs in health sciences.

majors.name: Chemical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Strong foundation in chemistry, physics, and mathematics.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Civil engineers build societies, from the landmarks that define who we are to the hidden infrastructure essential to our quality of life.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: All engineering majors require MTH 141. EAS 360 (STEM Communications) is also a required course for all SEAS majors.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: All engineering majors require MTH 141. EAS 360 (STEM Communications) is also a required course for all SEAS majors.
majors.notes: Often double majored with Aerospace Engineering.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Broad academic interests, strong foundational skills. Offers flexibility for exploring various disciplines.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms on both North and South Campuses. Access to general Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, diverse interests, analytical thinkers.

majors.name: Psychology
majors.notes: Psychology is a popular major at UB.

majors.name: Biology
majors.notes: Includes concentrations in Biological Sciences, Biomedical Sciences, Biochemistry, Biophysics, Exercise Physiology, Pharmacology and Toxicology, Bioinformatics, and Biotechnology.

majors.name: Economics
majors.special_requirements: BS in Economics requires 59 credits in Economics, minimum 2.5 GPA in Econ classes, minimum 2.0 overall GPA. All UB Economics majors must complete at least five upper-level (300+ level) economics electives at UB.
majors.notes: Master's in Economics programs do not accept transfer credits, but course waivers may be possible.

majors.name: Communication
majors.notes: Communication is listed as a popular major.

majors.name: English
majors.special_requirements: Transfer students may have up to six courses accepted, with no more than four at the 300 or 400 level at the discretion of the Director of Undergraduate Studies.
majors.notes: The department encourages freshmen to take 200-level survey courses for a sense of literary history.

majors.name: History
majors.special_requirements: Transfer students majoring in history may receive credit for up to five history courses (15 credit hours), but must take the two required 400-level seminars at UB.
majors.notes: No prerequisites for progression through the history major, but lower-level courses are encouraged before upper-level ones.

majors.name: Sociology
majors.special_requirements: Transfer students may transfer no more than five courses (15 credit hours) of appropriate sociology courses toward the major requirements.
majors.notes: Students interested in sociology can declare their major or minor after being accepted to UB.

majors.name: Mathematics
majors.special_requirements: UB requires the Math Readiness Assessment for students wishing to enroll in first semester calculus courses (MTH 121 or MTH 131/141). A score of 70 on Math Fundamentals and 70 on Advanced Algebra is needed.
majors.notes: Students can change to a Mathematics major or minor using the CAS Major/Minor Change Request form.

colleges.name: School of Management
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Focus on strong academic record; competitive admission for minors.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with opportunities for Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Career-focused, driven, collaborative, interested in business and economics.

majors.name: Business Administration
prerequisite_courses: MTH 121 (Survey of Calculus and Its Applications 1) or higher
majors.special_requirements: Direct admission to business management is subject to limited enrollment. Recommended to complete pre-calculus and be calculus-ready.
majors.notes: Most popular undergraduate major at UB. Strong reputation for Business Administration and MBA programs.

majors.name: Accounting
prerequisite_courses: MTH 121 (Survey of Calculus and Its Applications 1) or higher
majors.special_requirements: Direct admission to accounting is subject to limited enrollment. Junior-year admission to accounting is fall only. Recommended to complete pre-calculus and be calculus-ready.
majors.notes: No departmental application required at entry to UB.

colleges.name: School of Architecture and Planning
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: First-year BS Architecture applicants have no additional requirements beyond university admission. Transfer students need a minimum 2.70 overall GPA and 2.50 in architecture/related courses, and admission is space-available. Portfolio review is part of the graduate application process.
colleges.housing_profile: Themed living communities for architecture students (implied from 'architecture floors'). Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms.
colleges.student_archetype: Creative, design-oriented, community-focused, problem-solvers in urban and environmental contexts.

colleges.name: School of Law
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic record, competitive LSAT/GRE scores, compelling personal statement, strong recommendation letters, and demonstrated leadership, work experience, and community service.
colleges.housing_profile: Graduate student apartments (e.g., Flickinger Court for professional students) or off-campus housing. No on-campus residence halls at the Downtown Campus where the Law School is located.
colleges.student_archetype: Analytical, justice-driven, articulate, committed to public service and legal scholarship.

colleges.name: Jacobs School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Exceptional academic performance, competitive MCAT scores, strong letters of recommendation, diverse life experiences, and commitment to health and wellness. Prerequisite coursework is essential.
colleges.housing_profile: Graduate student apartments or off-campus housing. Some medical school facilities are on the South and Downtown Campuses.
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate, scientifically rigorous, dedicated to patient care and biomedical research, high academic achievers.

colleges.name: School of Nursing
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Competitive application process based on holistic review, including prerequisite, cumulative, and prerequisite science GPAs, video response, written essay, and resume. Minimum 3.0 overall prerequisite GPA and 3.0 overall GPA for traditional BS.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with access to Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Caring, resilient, dedicated to patient care, strong scientific and interpersonal skills.

colleges.name: School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong background in science; likely competitive given it's one of two pharmacy schools in SUNY.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with access to Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Detail-oriented, scientifically inclined, committed to healthcare and research in pharmaceuticals.

colleges.name: School of Public Health and Health Professions
colleges.admissions_model: Direct Admit (for BS) / Competitive (for combined degrees and graduate)
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Direct admission for BS in Public Health for new UB students. Combined BS/MPH requires a minimum 3.25 undergraduate GPA and 3.25 in PUB-prefix courses. Graduate admissions involve a personal statement and references.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms. Some facilities are on the South Campus.
colleges.student_archetype: Community-minded, analytical, passionate about improving public health outcomes and promoting healthy behaviors.

colleges.name: School of Dental Medicine
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong GPA, solid science foundation, competitive DAT score, and demonstrated compassion, service, critical thinking, and leadership skills are key.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with access to Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Precise, empathetic, dedicated to oral health, strong scientific aptitude and manual dexterity.

colleges.name: Graduate School of Education
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic background and commitment to education and research; likely varied requirements by program.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with access to Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Passionate about learning and teaching, community-focused, eager to shape future generations.

colleges.name: School of Social Work
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Dedication to social justice, strong interpersonal skills, and commitment to serving vulnerable populations.
colleges.housing_profile: Traditional dorms and suite-style rooms with access to Living Learning Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Empathetic, advocating, committed to social justice and community well-being.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences - Undecided/Exploratory
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students exploring interests; strong academic advising to help discover a major path.
colleges.housing_profile: The 'Major and Career Exploration Living and Learning Community' in Wilkeson Quad is specifically for undecided students.
colleges.student_archetype: Open-minded, curious, seeking direction, adaptable, eager to explore various academic fields.

minors_certificates: Classics Minor - Classical Languages and Literature Minor
Classics Minor - Greek and Roman Culture Minor
Human Factors and Ergonomics Engineering Minor

application_deadlines.notes: Non-binding; priority scholarship consideration for Fall entry
Application completion deadline for Fall entry; applications continue to be accepted until capacity is reached
Recommended application submission date for Spring 2026 entry; applications accepted until capacity is reached

supplemental_requirements.details: Submitted through the Common App, Coalition App, or SUNY Application, and considered in holistic review. Not a separate supplemental essay in addition to the main application essay.

Required for Honors College applicants: 'UB Honors scholars are characterized by intellectual curiosity, a broad range of interests, and a commitment to a diverse and inclusive society. What experiences have helped to broaden your perspectives academically, socially and culturally? What experiences do you hope to have that will enlarge your understanding of the cultural richness of America and the world? Please be as specific as possible in your answer.' (650 words)

supplemental_requirements.deadline: Ongoing for video auditions; specific in-person dates
supplemental_requirements.details: Required for Music majors and performance minors. In-person audition dates for 2025-2026 include November 7, 2025, January 24, 2026, February 8, 2026, February 20, 2026, March 1, 2026, March 29, 2026, and April 26, 2026. Video auditions are also accepted for prospective majors.
Program auditions scheduled for November 8, 2025, February 28, 2026, and March 28, 2026.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (Transfer/Current UB Students)
supplemental_requirements.notes: For new transfer students and current UB students seeking admission to SEAS.

supplemental_requirements.details: Secondary application with specific essay prompts for medical school applicants.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Holistic review assesses academic performance, MCAT scores (for medical school), integrity, intellectual curiosity, leadership roles, life experiences, and background. For general undergraduate admission, it looks for students who excel academically, engage in extracurricular activities, and maintain a good school-life balance.

major_selection_tactics: Consider majors aligning with personal interests and career goals, not solely perceived high-earning fields like CS/Engineering.
Explore less math-intensive fields such as Psychology (BA), Anthropology, Geography, Communications, Digital Arts, or Media Studies if strong in humanities.
Research UB's specializations (e.g., STEM, Business, Dentistry, Nursing) and areas with strong funding, noting potential cuts to liberal arts programs.
Utilize resources like the Focus2 assessment to identify potential major interests.
For competitive majors, be aware that fields like Biological Sciences often require extensive advising to navigate.
college_ranking_tactics: Prioritize colleges based on specific program strengths rather than general prestige, as UB is noted for STEM and Business.
Investigate tuition costs as a significant factor in decision-making.
Consider campus amenities, housing quality, and the vibrancy of off-campus life in your ranking.
Recognize that overall college rankings can be misleading; focus on institutional strengths (e.g., research focus for UB and Stony Brook).
Differentiate between University at Buffalo and SUNY Buffalo State College to ensure application to the correct institution.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a competitive major within a specific school (e.g., Computer Engineering in Engineering), research less competitive, related majors in different departments or colleges (e.g., ITM/MIS in Business, Economics, or Geography, or potentially a humanities major in a different college like Letters and Science) as a backup. Consult academic advisors early about major change requirements, especially GPA minimums, and consider taking general education courses initially to maintain flexibility.

scholarships.name: Presidential Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Up to $15,000 annually for NYS residents (not exceeding cost of attendance), up to $22,000 annually for out-of-state/international students, renewable for 4 years
scholarships.benefits: Participation in the University Honors College Presidential Scholars Program, Presidential Scholar Seminar (HON 101) in first semester, potential for full cost of attendance when combined with other aid.
scholarships.application_method: Separate application through the University Honors College, after applying for admission.

scholarships.name: Provost Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Varies (covers part of the cost of attendance), renewable
scholarships.benefits: Financial assistance for high-achieving domestic first-year out-of-state students.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration upon application for admission.

scholarships.name: Pride of New York Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Varies (covers non-tuition costs such as fees), renewable for 2 or 4 years
scholarships.benefits: Financial assistance for high-achieving first-year domestic students from New York State to cover non-tuition expenses.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration upon application for admission.

scholarships.name: NYS Excelsior Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Tuition-free attendance at a SUNY college
scholarships.deadline: Varies by academic year (managed by HESC)
scholarships.benefits: Covers tuition for eligible New York State residents from families earning $125,000 or less per year.
scholarships.application_method: Apply through the New York State Higher Education Services Corporation (HESC).

scholarships.name: School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) Scholarships
scholarships.deadline: Most scholarships open end of August and close in September (scholarship portal closes July 1 for previous year's applications)
scholarships.benefits: Financial support for undergraduate students pursuing degrees within SEAS.
scholarships.application_method: Complete the General Application and SEAS Conditional Application via the UB Scholarship Portal.

scholarships.name: UB General Philanthropic/Endowed Scholarships
scholarships.deadline: General Application open July 15, 2025 â€“ June 30, 2026 (for current students); after March 1st for newly accepted students for Summer/Fall 2026
scholarships.benefits: Support for various fields of study and student populations based on donor-specified criteria.
scholarships.application_method: Complete the General Application on the UB Scholarship Portal (may require supplemental questions for specific opportunities).

ap_policy.general_rule: An official score report from the College Board showing a minimum score of 3 on any AP Exam will guarantee elective credit for use toward a UB degree.
exceptions: In some cases, specific scores (e.g., 4 or 5 for English Language and Composition) may be more advantageous for direct course equivalency or to satisfy general education requirements over elective credit, and some departments may have specific articulation guidelines for majors (e.g., Calculus, Chemistry, Physics).
ap_policy.usage: Can satisfy elective credit, and in some cases, major or UB Curriculum (general education) requirements.

ib_policy.general_rule: Higher-level IB exams with scores of '5' or better are guaranteed credit.

tools: TAURUS (Transfer Articulation and University Requirements at UB System)
transfer_articulation.restrictions: UB accepts all college-level credits from regionally accredited two- and four-year degree-granting institutions. Articulation compares course content, not credit, and course credits transferred from institutions with other academic calendar systems will be converted to semester credits. Students are responsible for UB's Transfer Credit Policy, published yearly in the Undergraduate Catalog.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework, particularly in areas related to your intended major
Demonstrated intellectual curiosity, civic engagement, and resilience, especially for selective programs like the Honors College
A holistic application that showcases individual strengths and potential contributions to the UB community
For some graduate programs, strong performance on standardized tests (GMAT/GRE) is required
Proficiency and interest in specific fields, evidenced by challenging coursework and extracurricular participation
common_activities: Leadership roles in school clubs and organizations
Participation in varsity athletics (e.g., swimming, wrestling)
Community service and demonstrating a commitment to a diverse and inclusive society
Engagement in academic-related extracurriculars (e.g., Virtual Enterprise, Model Congress, software engineering, theology scholar, photography, hiking, political debates)
Involvement in campus events and taking advantage of various opportunities offered by the university
essay_tips: Be specific and demonstrate a clear understanding of and appreciation for intellectual curiosity, diversity, and inclusivity, especially for Honors College essays
Show, don't tell; use detailed, compelling examples from your experiences
Address your short- and long-term goals and articulate what you will bring to the program and classroom
Reference specific UB courses, resources, and opportunities to show genuine interest in the institution
Write a full, critically reflective essay (not Q&A format), double-spaced, 12-point font, focusing on key questions rather than a single paragraph
red_flags: Generic essays that could apply to any institution and don't reflect specific interest in UB
Submitting a one-paragraph personal statement, which is considered insufficient
Asking family members or significant others' family members for letters of recommendation
Not addressing academic challenges (e.g., GPA below 3.0, low grades, academic probation) through an addendum
Waiting until the last minute to complete the application, especially for essays and recommendation letters
insights: University at Buffalo is a moderately selective, top 100 research-intensive university with a diverse student body
The campus offers numerous clubs, activities, and events, contributing to a vibrant student life, and is considered by some to be a 'party school'
UB provides many opportunities for research, study abroad, and internships
Academic support services and professors are generally considered excellent and supportive
Applying early is recommended, particularly for scholarship consideration and for international applicants needing time for visa processes
